Message.Title: Kid was taught to SHOOT... not hunt
Message.Msg: Kid was taught to SHOOT... There have not been any reports that the kid ever went hunting. The issue is mental illness and how we recognize illness and what we do about it... (this should be something the libs are very interested in) Further gun laws will accomplish nothing and will probably be unconstitutional because they will create 2 classes of citizens... those that have guns and those that don't... (congress shall create "no ex post facto law") Criminals will always find a way to get their hands on one of 280 million+ guns in the US You will never be able to amend the constitution to allow ex post facto laws and there is a real question as to if the 2nd amendment could be taken away without wiping out the entire Bill Of Rights The only areas where I see congress being able to act is the size of magazines and perhaps making it a crime if someone has a mental illness and gains access to your legal guns... (remember Columbine HS massacre was right plumb in the middle of the previous assault rifle ban and the guns used there were covered by the ban) I could also easily see increased fees (taxes) on owning a small firearm Liberals have also been complaining on the "large calibre" of the weapons... the BushMaster .223 is a very small calibre weapon... of the 2 semi's that he had a 9mm is considered small calibre (thats significantly smaller than a .38).. the Sig was a 10mm..... which is the equivalent of a 40 cal... which is large... but I'll point out no where near as powerful as a .357

Topic.Title: the company earned 53 cents a share. Accounting magic once again gets .64?

Message.Msg: of the underlying business. It's a big difference if ORCL earnings are higher because of better software license sales or just because of currency tailwinds. On the other hand it doesn't mean anything for the ongoing business if they do a one time write-off of some goodwill (e.g. the SUN acquisition). So in most cases non-Gaap is the better way to look at things. For the rest the GAAP numbers are always there, too.
